AABB.definition: (Axis-Aligned Bounding Box) A Bounding box aligned with the axes of the coordinate system.

Buffer.definition: A section of memory used for temporary data storage.

BVH.definition: (Bounding Volume Hierarchy) An acceleration structure made of primitive 3D objects that speeds up ray-casting and various algorithms.

Camera Space.definition: 3D information of 3D coordinates projected relative to the camera. Includes relative depth.

Depth Buffer.definition: An additional screen-space buffer that provides depth information.

DOF.definition: (Depth of field) The distance between the nearest and the furthest objects that are in acceptably sharp focus in an image captured with a camera.

Epsilon.definition: A very small value, mostly used to prevent floating point inaccuracies and to set raymarching limits.

Focal length.definition: Camera property that indicates how strongly it converges or diverges light. Inversely proportional to the FOV.

FOV.definition: (Field of view) The angular extent of the world that is seen. Inversely proportional to the focal length.

Mesh.definition: A collection of faces, edges and vertices that define the object's shape.

Model Space.definition: 3D coordinates relative to another point of reference, typically used to store meshes of individual models/objects.

Normal.definition: A vector perpendicular to the surface of an object.

Pen.definition: A vanilla Scratch extension used to draw on the screen.

Rasterizer.definition: An algorithm which draws objects to the screen by filling in shapes pixel-by-pixel.

Ray.definition: Defined by its origin (a position in 3D space where the ray starts) and its direction (A vector parallel to the direction of the ray).

Screen Space.definition: 2D information of 3D coordinates projected to the screen. Does not include depth information.

SDF.definition: Signed distance field; a function defining distance to the surface of an object with interior points being negative, and exterior being positive.

Vector.definition: An object having direction as well as magnitude, especially as determining the position of one point in space relative to another.

Vertex.definition: A point with a coordinate vector.

Viewing Frustum.definition: The region of space in the modeled world that may appear on the screen.

World Space.definition: 3D coordinates relative to the center of the world, typically (0, 0, 0).
